user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_increment_response_rc:
```c
void
MHD_increment_response_rc (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  (response->reference_count)++;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: the code calls MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ rather than MHD_increment_response_rc. This does not constitute direct recursion. A rule 17.2 violation would occur only if MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (or some chain of calls it triggers) called MHD_increment_response_rc back (i.e., indirect recursion). There is no evidence of that in the provided code fragment.
